dataset.title: NH Department of Environmental Studies (NHDES): Watershed Management Bureau Volunteer Lakes Assessment Program Lake Sunapee, 1986-2012

abstract.para: Data on Lake Sunapee were compiled by Kathleen Weathers’ Lab, Cary Institute of Ecosystem Studies. Data were collected by Lake Sunapee Protective Association (LSPA) and analyzed by NH Department of Environmental Services (NHDES). LSPA has been concerned with water quality since its founding in 1898, when the issues were sawdust and trash in the lake and the level of the lake water. In the 1950’s LSPA collected water samples and tested for E.coli in order to have Lake Sunapee meet the standards to be named a class A (drinking water quality) lake in New Hampshire. Starting in the 1980’s, LSPA volunteer water quality monitors have been regularly sampling Lake Sunapee’s water in cove and deep sites in Lake Sunapee, and more recently in its tributary streams. The samples are analyzed in LSPA’s Water Quality Laboratory at Colby-Sawyer College; NH Department of Environmental Services provides an annual water quality report based on its analysis of the data as part of the VLAP (Volunteer Lake Assessment) Program. The LSPA lab at Colby-Sawyer College, run by Bonnie Lewis under strict quality standards as a sister lab to the state lab at NH Department of Environmental Services, also processes water samples for about twenty five area lakes.

section.title: Phosphorus, total
section.para:  Usually measured in epilimnion, metalimnion and, hypolimnion
 Composite sample from Kemmerer Bottle method
 Protocols available in New Hampshire Volunteers Lake Assessment Program Monitors’ Field Manual
 Detection limit unknown

section.title: Chlorophyll a
section.para:  Sample taken from the metalimnion in stratified lakes or at 2/3 of total depth in unstratified lakes
 Two Methods Used: Kemmerer Bottle and Integrated Tube
 Methods from “Numeric Nutrient Criteria for the Great Bay Estuary” – Protocol info available in New Hampshire Volunteers Lake Assessment Program Monitors’ Field Manual
 Detection limit unknown

section.title: QAQC
section.para: “LSPA has a long history of setting and maintaining standards of excellence in our water quality testing program. Starting in summer 2006, volunteer water quality monitors take a second set of samples at one site each sampling date. The volunteer and site change each time, so that each date during the sampling season one monitor collects a field duplicate sample.

The duplicate sample is analyzed in the lab along with the regular sample, as another quality control tool that we can use to ensure valid results – by analyzing two samples taken from the same place at the same time we are able to get a better idea of how accurately our data represent actual conditions. The routine collection and analysis of field duplicate samples will further boost the credibility and legitimacy of our entire testing program.”

samplingDescription.para: Water quality data have been collected at Lake Sunapee since 1986. Every year VLAP volunteers collect data from four deep spot stations, nine near shore stations and numerous tributary stations. Samples are typically collected between June and September, with occasional samples in May and October. Sampling is conducted at a frequency that varies from 1 sample to 2 samples per month.
